Basically means the electron and the proton have the same charge (the elementary charge or e), but in the electron, the charge is negative while in the proton, the charge is positive. Hope this clears it up.

@somerandomguynumber111  You know, if the electron has the charge "e" proton must have the charge "-e" (read out as like negative e) since they have opposite charges. And she has stated 2 charges for electron, so the electron has a charge of both e and negative e, which is impossible.

@user-nt7lt2xf8i  when she said the charge of an electron is the elementary charge, she did not specify if it was positive or negative. She later added that the proton is positive while the electron is negative. So electron is equal to -e while proton is +e.
@somerandomguynumber111  Charge is not a quantity of magnitude only, when you only say "charge" it refers to a real value not positive real
@user-nt7lt2xf8i  well protons are positive while electrons are negative. So their charges will have the corresponding signs.

The voltage between two terminals in an open circuit can be approximately the same voltage drop over the load. however the voltage drop over a length of wire that would by pass the load will be zero. The division by a square represents the lines of force as though they were taken as an integrated surface a particular distance from the centre of their emission, that is to say, the surface of an imaginary sphere. If there was only one type of charge there would effectively be no charge since it would all be the same and there would be no interaction between things of different charge. Since charge is a binary concept there is no concept of what a third charge would be. It would be like asking what would happen if people were alive and dead at the same time.

1.  Because glass and cloth are not good conductors (that is, they are insulators), which means that current does not flow easily, or at all, in them.  2. The nature of the material.  Some elements give up electrons easily, others grab them easily.  3. Because they are isolated by insulators.  That is, there is no conductor connecting them to something else that can take or give up electrons.
3. By insulators, do u refer to the floor and shoes and socks and stuff? So if I were to stand, barefoot, on bare Earth, would I be incapable of building up a static charge?
